Award.AwardTitle: Galois Representations, Monodromy Groups, and Motives
Award.AbstractNarration:
Throughout the mathematical sciences, symmetry is a powerful organizing principle. In number theory, which studies the integers, especially the prime numbers, there are no manifest symmetries of the kind encountered in more intuitive, geometric settings (symmetry of a square under 90-degree rotations, etc.). Nevertheless, much of our deepest knowledge of the primes comes from their connections with the "symmetries" of polynomial equations. This project focuses on the study of Galois representations, which are natural packages for this information about the prime numbers. One of the central programs of modern number theory, initiated by Robert Langlands, proposes new ways to "unpack" Galois representations by relating them to remarkably different mathematical objects arising in geometry. Although they are essentially about the prime numbers, these relations have even had reverberations in fundamental physics. This project involves both constructing new Galois representations and unpacking the information they contain in the light of Langlands' conjectures.

This project comprises two research programs. The first will study deformations of Galois representations valued in arbitrary reductive groups, with a view toward establishing in as great generality as possible the existence of geometric p-adic deformations of a given mod p representation. The work is likely to furnish steps toward generalizations of Serre's modularity conjecture to general reductive groups. Such geometric p-adic representations are expected to be the (semi-simple) Galois representations occurring in the cohomology of algebraic varieties over number fields. The second program aims to study a number of questions of Fontaine-Mazur type, seeking to establish the motivic origin of certain Galois representations or, in a more geometric setting, local systems over a curve. The work will require elaborating the motivic structures underlying basic objects of the geometric Langlands program, a problem that should be of long-term independent interest even for the arithmetic Langlands program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the PI's research in algebraic number theory and arithmetic geometry, that research in turn being the foundation of the research of 5 of the PI's PhD students. The context of the PI's work is the Langlands program, which has since the 1960's been one of the driving research programs in number theory. The Langlands program centers on conjectural connections between three seemingly quite different mathematical realms: motives, Galois representations, and automorphic forms. As with so much of modern mathematics, these sophisticated objects have developed over centuries as the most meaningful and robust ways to encode and further study classical problems in arithmetic and geometry. Galois representations constitute the most productive modern language for studying the internal symmetries of polynomial equations (with rational coefficients, for example), and for relating these symmetries, as the Langlands program postulates, to the topology of algebraic varieties (encoded by motives) and to automorphic forms. Central to this project has been the deformation theory of Galois representations, which studies how a Galois representation modulo some prime p can be deformed, or lifted, to a representation with coefficients in the ring of p-adic integers. This kind of deformation theory has been one of the key tools in the Langlands program since its dramatic use in the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem and the Shimura-Taniyama conjecture (automorphy of elliptic curves) by Wiles. The PI's work has dramatically enhanced understanding of the deformation theory of Galois representations, particularly through his three joint papers with N. Fakhruddin and C. Khare. These prove by far the most general results in the subject and have introduced new ideas that promise to have further applications to the automorphy of p-adic Galois representations, as predicted by the Langlands program. Some of these applications are already in evidence, as the PI has with Fakhruddin and Khare deduced from their deformation theory results the automorphy of many mod p reducible Galois representations.

A focal point of the PI's work has been the study of Galois representations, or more generally fundamental group representations, valued in arbitrary reductive groups. A representation of dimension n of a group G is an action of G on an n-dimensional vector space (over some specified field, such as the integers modulo a prime p, or the field of p-adic numbers). Many representations encountered in number theory, and certainly pervading the Langlands program, are or are expected to satisfy additionally symmetries (fixing certain tensors, for instance), and these are most fruitfully studied by considering representations instead valued in general reductive groups (the case of GL(n) corresponding to the case of ordinary n-dimensional representations). The PI's work has systematically developed this perspective, both by developing tools applicable in this full generality, and by focusing on the construction of unusual examples valued in "exceptional" reductive groups. Along with the joint work mentioned above, the PI's joint work with J. Booher studies the geometry of local Galois deformation rings valued in general groups. The PI's joint work with his PhD student C. Klevdal establishes a conjecture of Simpson that "rigid" fundamental group representations (valued in any reductive group) should preserve a lattice, a necessary condition for, and stepping-stone toward, Simpson's fundamental conjecture that such representations are motivic. Finally the PI has with G. Boxer, F. Calegari, M. Emerton, B. Levin, and K. Madapusi Pera constructed the first motivic examples of Galois representations whose natural symmetry group is the exceptional group E6, through a combination of deformation-theoretic and automorphic methods.

In all, the PI's attention in this project to the intrinsic symmetries--or the natural "monodromy group"--of fundamental group and Galois representations has forged new collaborations, trained PhD students in number theory, and contributed new ideas that will continue to stimulate research in the arithmetic geometry and number theory surrounding the Langlands program.
